candidates.title: Handle verification of keys using elliptic curve
candidates.body:
This PR introduces support for handling certificates using elliptic curve public keys.

~~Only signature verification is currently implemented.~~
**Update:** Both signature creation and verification are supported.

The implementation relies on the `ring` crate, which currently is the only one capable of supporting both ECDSA p256 and ECDSA p384.

~~I haven't yet extended the unit tests. I'm looking forward to hear your feedback about this contribution. I think this is something you're interested about (see #100). I wonder if this is going in the direction you like.~~
**Update:** The unit tests have been extended too

candidates.title: Add DLL version info on Windows
ffi: rename native lib for nuget
Expose X509 cert API to C#
DPS-5446: expose SSH certificates API to C#
candidates.body:
New approach for bindings based on [these experiments](https://github.com/CBenoit/dotnet-to-rust-bindgen-experiments).

cc @awakecoding

candidates.title: Fix signing UTF-8/16 powershell scripts
candidates.body:
Bug fixes _PowerShell_ scripts signing:
- Fix signing _UTF16_ LE/BE _PowerShell_ scripts. 
- If a character in a _PS_ script is not valid, encode it as a _REPLACEMENT CHARACTER_ (�) for file hash calculation. It's how _singtool_ does. Previously signing a script with an invalid character causes the signature to be invalid, although _signtool_ can handle such a script. The bug was discovered with [PSLogging](https://github.com/9to5IT/PSLogging).

candidates.title: Initial C API and C# .NET wrapper
candidates.body:
This is the C API and C# .NET wrapper MVP implementation.

FFI-wise, the Rust files are the single source of truth, everything else is generated and checked against it.

C# bindings are available in two flavors: the unsafe native API (auto-generated extern functions mapped to the native library), and the safe idiomatic C# API intended to be used in most situations by user code.

I chose to expose the `picky::pem` module as a first try because it is small and complex enough.

Next modules to expose are:
-  `picky::key`,
- `picky::hash`,
- `picky::jose`,
- `picky::http`,
-  `picky::x509`,
- and `picky::ssh`.

On C# side, the last remaining bit is to write the NuGet manifest and tell where native libraries are located. I hardcoded path to `./target/debug/libpicky.so` in the `.csproj`, but we'll need to package binaries at least for x64 and x86 architectures (probably arm64 too?) for all supported platforms (Windows and Linux only? Do we support Mac as well?).

`c-api`'s [README](https://github.com/Devolutions/picky-rs/tree/c03bf71e4dc6835e22f3b15e44d402f3c6f2693c/c-api) also contains a few additional information.

@thenextman @awakecoding @fdubois1 any thoughts?

candidates.title: SSH certificate support
candidates.body:
I implemented _SSH_ certificate authority in **picky**. The feature is intended to be used for _SSH_ certificate authentication implementation in DVLS someday. You can find more about _SSH CA_ [here](https://smallstep.com/blog/use-ssh-certificates/), and [how to set up it](https://berndbausch.medium.com/ssh-certificates-a45bdcdfac39) This code includes the construct blocks for the _SSH_ certificate authentication, like:
1. Decoding and encoding _SSH public_, private keys, and _SSH_ certificates.
2. Generating _SSH_ private key and _SSH_ certificate.
3. _SSH_ certificate authority in **picky-server**. 
**picky-server** can now issue an _SSH_ certificate by signing an _SSH_ public key. _SSH_ public keys are divided into host and client based on how the final certificate is intended to be used in an _SSH_ certificate authentication. **picky-server** contains the host and client _SSH_ private keys for signing a host public and a client public keys respective. **picky-server** private keys are stored encrypted into a **PickyStorage**. The keys are encrypted with a password that an admin can specify through _CLI_ arguments or defaults in use. I added regenerating an _SSH_ private key if a password does not match, with that password. **picky-server** new the following _REST_ endpoints:
- `/ssh/sign_key` - signs an incoming _SSH_ public key. It expects _JWT_ encoded _SshSignRequest_(you can see in code how it looks like :slightly_smiling_face:) and responses with an _SSH_ certificate. 
- `/ssh/client_ssh_key` - responses with the public key of the client private key.
- `/ssh/host_ssh_key` - responses with the public key of the host private key.

You might find the following resources useful for reviewing:
[_SSH_ certificates format.](https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/PROTOCOL.certkeys)
[_SSH_ private key format.](https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/PROTOCOL.keyl)
A Go implementation of parsing all the _SSH_ stuff [here](https://cs.opensource.google/go/x/crypto/+/master:ssh/keys.go) and [here](https://cs.opensource.google/go/x/crypto/+/master:ssh/certs.go).
[Data type representations used in the SSH.](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4251#section-5)

candidates.title: Implement `time 0.3` types conversion
candidates.body: I also migrated to 2021 editions `picky`, `picky-server` and `picky-signtool`.

candidates.title: Fix Authenticode bugs that were found by QA
candidates.body:
Fix that we cannot sign with just an end-entry self-signed root certificate.
Fix that `output` CLI parameter is required for verifying a binary.

candidates.title: Authenticode timestamping
candidates.body:
Added support for Authenticode timestamping for picky-signtool, and made Authenticode TSA server from picky-server.
There are two Authenticode timestamp protocols:
1) "Default" - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/seccrypto/time-stamping-authenticode-signatures.
2) RFC3161
I have implemented the first one, but I was keeping in mind that we might add the second one. For Authenticode TSA server with default protocol, we don't need to use the database, but I added counting issued Authenticode timestamps as RFC3161 requires it, and we might add support for RFC3161 someday.
For timestamping Authenticode signature with picky-singtool, somebody should add `--timestamp <Authenticode TSA server URL>` arg.
